title: The potential of this data package
text: Figure 1. TTS 2016 study area within Greater Golden Horseshoe Ontario, Canada. Table 1. Descriptive statistics Persons, workers, jobs traffic analysis zones (TAZ) TTS 2016 data set along estimated car origin-destination travel times. terms commute data, data package includes data related full-time employed population place residence (origin), full-time usual place work (destination), number trips work mode calculated potential travel time trips Greater Golden Horseshoe (GGH) area. data aggregated available level TAZ: TAZ spatial unit analysis typically used estimate number trips produced attracted zone. thus defined transportation planners region based intra-similarity inter-dissimilarity land-use population demographics. Within TTS, 3,764 TAZ. TAZ unique identifier corresponds GTA06 Zoning System. survey boundaries discussed 2016 TTS methodology defined TTS (Data Management Group 2018). TAZ range \(\ge\) 0.019 km2 spatial area maximum 879 km2 (median: 1.3 km2 3rd quantile: 2.8 km2). number jobs (3,081,900) workers (3,446,957) organized form origin-destination (OD) table. data retrieved Transportation Tomorrow Survey Data Retrieval System October 28, 2021 reflect potential interaction full-time employed people jobs within GGH survey boundaries shown Figure 1. Also included {TTS2016R} travel times cost travel origin destination car; travel times calculated using {r5r} package (Pereira et al. 2021). travel times useful estimate cost travel calculate impedance functions, among possible uses. important note simplicity, interactions within {TTS2016R} assumed taken car, travel time calculated origin TAZ centroid destination TAZ centroid. centroid snapped nearest street line {r5r} travel time calculated trips assuming car travel mode. Additionally, travel times less equal 180 mins (3 hrs) calculated; threshold represents 99% trip’s travel times summarized descriptive statistics Table 1.
code: #plot  ggplot() +   geom_sf(data = TTS2016R::ggh_pd,           fill = "gainsboro", color = "darkgray") +   geom_sf(data = group_ggh_pd_poly,            color = "steelblue", fill = NA, size = 0.7) +   annotation_north_arrow(location = "tl", # north arrow for both the main plot and inset                          height = unit(0.8, "cm"),                           width = unit(0.8, "cm"),                          style = north_arrow_orienteering(line_width = 0.25,                                                           line_col = "dimgrey",                                                            fill = c("white","dimgrey"))) +   annotation_scale(bar_cols = c("dimgrey", "white"), # scale bar for both the main plot and inset                    height = unit(0.15, "cm")) +    geom_shadowtext(data = group_ggh_pd,                   aes(x = X, y = Y, label = REGION_name),                   size = 2.5,                   nudge_y = 3000,                   nudge_x = 2000) +   theme_minimal() +   theme(legend.position = "none",         axis.title = element_blank())

code: tts_workers <- tm_shape(ggh_taz) +   tm_fill(col = "workers", title = "Full-time employed people", palette = "-Spectral", style = "jenks") +   tm_compass(type = "arrow", position = c("left", "top"), size = 2) +   tm_scale_bar(breaks = c(0, 30, 60), text.size = 0.5, position = c("left", "bottom")) +   tm_layout(legend.position = c("right", "bottom"))  tts_jobs <- tm_shape(ggh_taz) +   tm_fill(col = "jobs", title = "Full-time jobs", palette = "-Spectral", style = "jenks") +   tm_compass(type = "arrow", position = c("left", "top"), size = 2) +   tm_scale_bar(breaks = c(0, 30, 60), text.size = 0.5, position = c("left", "bottom")) +   tm_layout(legend.position = c("right", "bottom"))  tmap_arrange(tts_workers, tts_jobs) Number <- rbind(ggh_taz$jobs %>% data.frame(),                  ggh_taz$workers %>% data.frame()) Group <- rbind(rep("Jobs", each=length(ggh_taz$jobs)) %>% data.frame(),                 rep("Workers", each=length(ggh_taz$workers))%>% data.frame())  ecdf_data <- cbind(Number, Group) colnames(ecdf_data) <- c("Number", "Group")  rect1 <- data.frame(xmin=115, xmax=3055, ymin=-Inf, ymax=Inf)    ggplot(ecdf_data , aes(x=Number, col=Group)) +    # geom_segment(aes(x = 115, y = 0, xend = 115, yend = 0.34), col = "blue", linetype=2) +   # geom_segment(aes(x = 3055, y = 0, xend = 3055, yend = 0.94), col = "blue", linetype=2) +   geom_rect(data = rect1, aes(xmin=xmin, xmax=xmax, ymin=ymin, ymax=ymax), fill="lightblue", alpha=0.2, inherit.aes = FALSE) +   stat_ecdf() +    scale_x_continuous(trans='sqrt', breaks=c(115, 3055, 10000, 20000, 30000, 40000)) +    scale_y_continuous(breaks=c(0, 0.25,0.34, .50, .75,0.94, 1.00)) +   labs(x = "Opportunities per TAZ",        y = "Cumulative probability") +        scale_color_manual("Opportunities",                           values = c("Jobs" = "Black",                                     "Workers" = "Red"))+   scale_linetype_manual("Opportunities",values=c(0,1)) +   geom_point(aes(x = 115, y = 0.34), col = "blue")+   geom_point(aes(x=3055, y=0.94), col = "blue") +   theme_minimal() +   theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust=0.5),         legend.position = c(0.90,0.75),         axis.line = element_line(colour = "black"),         panel.border = element_blank())

title: The potential of this data package
text: {TTS2016R} also includes travel time data home--work trip displayed Figure 4. travel time corresponds car commute calculated using R package {r5r} interpreted network distance travel time full-time work commute GGH. travel times calculated assuming following input parameters: maximum travel time less equal 180 mins (3 hrs) street network retrieved OpenStreetMaps GGH area. 3 hr threshold selected captures 99% trip taken (see travel times summarized Table 1. important note travel times within data set reflect car travel, centroids origins destinations, uncongested street network. assumptions completely realistic, done generalization due data limitations. car mode commuting still critically important, 79% work trips made way. Additionally, finer resolutions data average departure times publicly available TTS Data Retrieval System. , include number mode-specific trips OD pair user can make mode- associated travel time/cost specific assumptions.  Figure 4. Estimated total worker travel time (top) average worker travel time (bottom) TAZ GGH. Travel times reflect uncongested car travel origin centroid destination centroid. can observed Figure 4, total travel time (min) resembles spatial trend distribution number employed people previous plot (Figure 2). However, average travel time per trip TAZ presented, spatial distribution distinct plots presented far. can see areas around south-eastern border make Greater Toronto Hamilton Area (GTHA) (e.g., Hamilton, Halton, Peel, Toronto, York, Durham) Niagara Waterloo, average travel times moderately low. areas, travel times higher. Interestingly, even eastern areas (e.g., Peterborough) high employment high job concentration, average travel time higher within GTHA.
code: # remove all NA trips from dataset and set all 0min travel times to 0.1 min od  <- TTS2016R::od %>%    filter( !is.na(travel_time)) %>%    mutate(travel_time = ifelse(travel_time == 0, 0.1, travel_time))  all_tt <- od  %>%    dplyr::select(Persons, travel_time)  all_tt <- all_tt[rep(seq_len(dim(all_tt)[1]), all_tt$Persons), 2]  #fitting impedance function gamma_ <- fitdistrplus::fitdist(data=all_tt, "gamma", method="mle", optim.method="Nelder-Mead") # transfer calibrated impedance function values to OD matrix od <- od %>%   mutate(f = dgamma(travel_time, gamma_$estimate["shape"], gamma_$estimate["rate"]))  #add the number of jobs and workers to the od matrix od_ft <- od %>% merge(ggh_taz %>% dplyr::select(GTA06, workers) %>% st_drop_geometry(),                    by.x = "Origin", by.y="GTA06", all.x = TRUE)  od_ft <- od_ft %>% merge(ggh_taz %>% dplyr::select(GTA06, jobs) %>% st_drop_geometry(),                    by.x = "Destination", by.y="GTA06", all.x = TRUE)  #calculate accessibility for workers from any origin to jobs in Toronto  GGH_c_accessibility <- od_ft %>%    mutate(GGH_A_ij = f * jobs) %>%   group_by(Origin) %>%   summarise(GGH_A_i = sum(GGH_A_ij, na.rm = T),             GGH_sum_tt_i = sum(travel_time),             GGH_tt_trips_i = mean(travel_time),             GGH_sum_f_i = sum(f),             GGH_f_trips_i = mean(f))  #Merge TO accessibly calculation to the ggh_taz: GGH_taz_acc <- ggh_taz %>% merge(GGH_c_accessibility, by.x=c("GTA06"), by.y=c("Origin"), all.x=T) tts_total_tt <- tm_shape(GGH_taz_acc) +   tm_fill(col = "GGH_sum_tt_i", title = "Total travel time\n per TAZ (min)", palette = "-Spectral", style = "jenks") +   tm_compass(type = "arrow", position = c("left", "top"), size = 2) +   tm_scale_bar(breaks = c(0, 30, 60), text.size = 0.5, position = c("left", "bottom")) +   tm_layout(legend.position = c("right", "bottom"))  tts_tt_per_trip <- tm_shape(GGH_taz_acc) +   tm_fill(col = "GGH_tt_trips_i", title = "Avg. travel time\n per TAZ (min)", palette = "-Spectral", style = "jenks") +   tm_compass(type = "arrow", position = c("left", "top"), size = 2) +   tm_scale_bar(breaks = c(0, 30, 60), text.size = 0.5, position = c("left", "bottom")) +   tm_layout(legend.position = c("right", "bottom"))  tmap_arrange(tts_total_tt, tts_tt_per_trip)

title: The potential of this data package
text: Impedance functions useful understand mobility behavior part, instance, gravity models spatial interaction (Wilson 1971; Haynes Fotheringham 1985) accessibility analysis many applications (Hansen 1959; Levinson 1998; Talen Anselin 1998; Reggiani, Bucci, Russo 2011; Páez et al. 2013; Kuai Zhao 2017; Barboza et al. 2021). OD matrix cost matrix (.e., travel times) can used combination estimate impedance functions. impedance function \(f(\cdot)\) depends cost travel locations \(\) \(j\) \(c_{ij}\); usually monotonically decreasing function, although sometimes function can increase reflect patterns separation activities; instance, separation land uses means short commuting trips relatively rare. can also fluctuations due hierarchical patterns, travelers bypass opportunities favor distant destinations offer economies agglomeration. useful technique calibrate impedance function use trip length distribution (TLD) measured origin-destination data (Horbachov Svichynskyi 2018; Batista, Leclercq, Geroliminis 2019). TLD representation likelihood proportion trips taken specific travel cost. data set, assume cost travel time, impedance function maps low travel times higher proportions trips, high travel times mapped low proportion trips.  Figure 5. Empirical TTS 2016 home-based car trip length distribution (black) calibrated gamma distribution impedance function (red) associated Q-Q P-P plots.  Figure 6. Cullen frey graph 2016 TTS calculated travel times. GGH data presented, empirical TLD (.e., proportion trips taken vs. travel time minutes) fitted density distribution using maximum likelihood techniques Nelder-Mead method direct optimization available within fitdistrplus package (Delignette-Muller Dutang 2015). Based goodness--fit criteria diagnostics seen Figure 5 Figure 6, gamma distribution selected presented data. resulting calibrated impedance function given following general form estimated ‘shape’ \(\alpha\) = 0.831, estimated ‘rate’ \(\beta\) = 0.044 , \(\Gamma(\alpha)\) defined Equation (1). \[\begin{equation} \begin{array}{l}\ f(x, \alpha, \beta) = \frac {x^{\alpha-1}e^{-\frac{x}{\beta}}}{ \beta^{\alpha}\Gamma(\alpha)} \quad \text{} 0 \leq x \leq \infty\\ \Gamma(\alpha) =  \int_{0}^{\infty} x^{\alpha-1}e^{-x} \,dx\\ \end{array} \end{equation}\]\end{equation}

title: The potential of this data package
text: noted , impedance functions essential component accessibility analysis. Equation (2) shows accessibility \(A_i\) weighted sum opportunities can reached location \(\), given cost travel \(c_{ij}\). Summing opportunities neighborhood \(\) defined impedance function \(f(\cdot)\), provides estimates number opportunities can reached \(\) certain cost. \[\begin{equation} A_i = \sum_{j=1}^JO_jf(c_{ij}) \end{equation}\] : \(\) accessibility. \(\) set origin locations. \(j\) set destination locations. \(O_j\) number opportunities location \(j\). opportunities activity add sort supply area; \(c_{ij}\) measure cost moving \(\) \(j\) \(f(\cdot)\) impedance function \(c_{ij}\).  Figure 7. Accessibility (top) normalized accessibility (bottom) employment GGH area. Accessibility property origin (.e., origin TAZ data), landscape opportunities (.e., TAZ destinations data), transportation infrastructure (.e., travel time table). Figure 7 presents accessibility estimates result impedance function calibrated preceding section. top plot, raw accessibility values, presents distinct radial trend majority TAZ around Toronto high accessibility values values gradually decrease TAZ Toronto’s boundary. Alternatively, bottom plot Figure 7 presents worker-normalized accessibility values. words, accessibility value TAZ divided number workers TAZ. patterns plot similar Greater Toronto Area radial trend observed top plot less extreme (.e., smaller spread).
code: GGH_taz_acc <- GGH_taz_acc %>%   mutate(avg_A_per_W = GGH_A_i/workers) ## accessibility access_TTS_GGH <- tm_shape(GGH_taz_acc) +   tm_fill(col = "GGH_A_i", title = "Accessibility \n(A_i)", palette = "-Spectral", style = "jenks") +   tm_compass(type = "arrow", position = c("left", "top"), size = 2) +   tm_scale_bar(breaks = c(0, 30, 60), text.size = 0.5, position = c("left", "bottom")) +   tm_layout(legend.position = c("right", "bottom"))  access_normalized_TTS_GGH <- tm_shape(GGH_taz_acc) +   tm_fill(col = "avg_A_per_W", title = "Average accessibility \nper worker", palette = "-Spectral", style = "jenks") +   tm_compass(type = "arrow", position = c("left", "top"), size = 2) +   tm_scale_bar(breaks = c(0, 30, 60), text.size = 0.5, position = c("left", "bottom")) +   tm_layout(legend.position = c("right", "bottom"))  tmap_arrange(access_TTS_GGH, access_normalized_TTS_GGH)

title: An augmented 2016 Transportation Tomorrow Survey (TTS) data package: worker and place of employment counts, trips and estimated travel time to work in the Greater Golden Horsehoe area, Canada
text: 2016 Transportation Tomorrow Survey (TTS) data Greater Golden Horseshoe (GGH), area located within province Ontario, Canada (43.6°N 79.73°W). Included within associated municipality boundaries, boundaries Traffic Analysis Zones (TAZ), table number full-time jobs associated full-time workers TAZ, trips (primary mode) origin (residential TAZ) destination (workplace TAZ). Also included calculated travel times car (calculated via r5r) derived impedance function values corresponding cost travel based trip length distribution.  plot follows spatial visualization number workers jobs within TAZ:  See .Rmd files \data-raw folder additional details included data sets compiled. See vignettes detailed examples using data sets comparing comparison different accessibility measures.

title: An augmented 2016 Transportation Tomorrow Survey (TTS) data package: worker and place of employment counts, trips and estimated travel time to work in the Greater Golden Horsehoe area, Canada

Analysis files reviewed added articles (full credit).

text: package includes count workers (origin), count places employment (destination), count associated trip (primary modes) origin destination, estimated car travel times origins destinations. data retireved 2016 Transportation Tomorrow Survey [TTS](http://dmg.utoronto.ca/transportation-tomorrow-survey/tts-introduction), travel survey Greater Golden Horse area (GGH) located southern Ontario, Canada. packages associated spatial boundaries faciliate analysis including: traffic analysis zone (TAZ) boundaries (retrieved TTS 2016), planning boundaries associated muncipalities (retrieved TTS 2016), census metropolitan areas (CMA) census aggloomeration (CA) boundaries retrieved Canadian Census. data package consists objects sourced 2016 Transportation Tomorrow Survey (TTS) curated facilitate use analysis TTS data. package includes worker--jobs origin -destinations traffic analysis zone (TAZ) boundaries Greater Golden Horse area (GGH) located southern Ontario, Canada. package also includes associated spatial boundary files.

title: census metropolitan area (CMA)/census agglomeration (CA) boundaries in the Greater Golden Horseshoe (GGH) area and associated data. — ggh_cma
census metropolitan area (CMA)/census agglomeration (CA) boundaries in the Greater Golden Horseshoe (GGH) area and associated data. — ggh_cma
text: simple feature class (sf) polygon object containing 16 rows 4 variables; row represents unique census metropolitan area (CMA) census agglomeration (CA) associated geo-referenced geometry. CMA CA consist one adjacent municipalities around core. CMA/CA boundaries defined purpose Canadian Census based population. , core CMA must population least 50,000 entire CMA must population least 100,000. CA smaller population, thir course must population least 10,000. CMAUID unique identifier census metropolitan area (CMA)/census agglomeration (CA). CMANAME name census metropolitan area (CMA)/census agglomeration (CA). CMATYPE one character field indicating whether unit census metropolitan area, tracted census agglomeration non-tracted census agglomeration. "B" CMA "D" CA census tracts, "K" CA census tracts. geometry sfc polygon geometry (boundaries).

title: Traffic analysis zones boundaries in the Greater Golden Horseshoe (GGH) area and associated data. — ggh_taz
Traffic analysis zones boundaries in the Greater Golden Horseshoe (GGH) area and associated data. — ggh_taz
text: simple feature class (sf) polygon object containing 3764 rows 10 variables; row represents unique TAZ associated features. GTA06 Unique ID traffic analysis zone (TAZ). AREA Area TAZ units km^2. REGION Retrieved ggh_pd object. unique ID corresponding greater region planning district (PD) part filtering analysis, PD, simplified. CMAUID Retrieved ggh_cma object. unique identifier census metropolitan area (CMA)/census agglomeration (CA). Within, filtering analysis can easily linked census data, simplified. workers number full-time workers TAZ. jobs number full-time workers declare typical place employment TAZ. LTGO_split percentage full-time work related trips made origin destination using local transit /GO transit (regional transit) primary mode. W_split percentage full-time work related trips made origin destination using bicyle primary mode. BC_split percentage full-time work related trips made origin destination walking primary mode. geometry sfc polygon geometry (boundaries) TAZ.

what: An origin and destination table of workers, place of employment, trip counts, and estimated travel times. — od
title: An origin and destination table of workers, place of employment, trip counts, and estimated travel times. — od
text: object contains trips made origin (TAZ) destination (TAZ) full-time workers work destinations; sourced 2016 Transportation Tomorrow Survey (TTS) Greater Golden Horseshoe (GGH) area. Also contained within calculated car travel time trip calculated using TAZ centroids r5r October 2021.

title: An origin and destination table of workers, place of employment, trip counts, and estimated travel times. — od
An origin and destination table of workers, place of employment, trip counts, and estimated travel times. — od
text: dataframe containing 103076 rows 17 variables; row represents unique trip origin TAZ destination TAZ associated features. Origin unique ID origin traffic analysis zone (TAZ). equivalent IDs used 'GTA06'. Destination unique ID destination traffic analysis zone (TAZ). equivalent IDs used 'GTA06'. Persons number full-time workers origin work destination. T_LT number work-related trips taken origin destination local transit excluding GO transit (regional transit service) primary mode. T_LTGO number work-related trips taken origin destination local transit GO transit (regional transit service) primary mode. T_GO number work-related trips taken origin destination GO transit (regional transit service primary mode. BC number work-related trips taken origin destination bicyle (primary mode). W number work-related trips taken origin destination walking (primary mode). C_DPC number work-related trips taken origin destination driver private car (primary mode). C_PPC number work-related trips taken origin destination passenger private car (primary mode). C_TA number work-related trips taken origin destination taxi (primary mode). C_RS number work-related trips taken origin destination paid ride-share  (primary mode). C_SB number work-related trips taken origin destination school bus (primary mode). M number work-related trips taken origin destination motorcycle (primary mode). O number work-related trips taken origin destination another mode (primary mode). sum_trips total number work-related trips taken origin destination modes. travel_time car travel time origin destination assuming 7:00 departure TAZ centroids Oct. 20 2021.
